content.text:
Wait for both "Read Research Files" and "Read Code Files" sub-agents to complete, then compile all the file contents into a single comprehensive message to send via Telegram.

The message should have this structure:

# ðŸ“¦ COMPLETE FILES - SPORTS BETTING MODEL SYSTEM

Return the complete message with ALL file contents inserted. This will allow the user to recreate all files after volume deployment.

content.thinking:
I need to wait for two sub-agents to complete their tasks:
1. "Read Research Files" sub-agent
2. "Read Code Files" sub-agent

Then I need to read the following files and compile them into a single message:

Research Documentation:
- memory/nba-player-prop-research.md
- memory/mlb-pitcher-prop-research.md
- memory/data-sources.md
- memory/open-source-betting-models.md

Code Files:
- sports-betting/requirements.txt
- sports-betting/src/database.py
- sports-betting/src/data_fetcher.py
- sports-betting/main.py

However, I don't have a direct way to "wait" for sub-agents. I need to check if the files exist or if there's some indication that the sub-agents have completed their work. Let me first check if these files exist in the workspace.

Actually, looking at the task more carefully - I'm supposed to compile the file contents. The sub-agents may have already created/read these files. Let me just read all the files directly and compile them.

Let me start by reading all the files.

content.text: I'll read all the files and compile them into the comprehensive message. Let me gather all the file contents now.</think>I'll compile all the files now. Let me read them and create the comprehensive message.<tool_call>grep cat memory/nba-player-prop-research.md memory/mlb-pitcher-prop-research.md memory/data-sources.md memory/open-source-betting-models.md sports-betting/requirements.txt sports-betting/src/database.py sports-betting/src/data_fetcher.py sports-betting/main.py 2>/dev/null || find . -name "*.md" -o -name "*.py" -o -name "*.txt" | head -20</think><tool_call>find . -path ./memory -prune -o -type f -print | head -30</arg_value><tool_call>find memory -type f -name "*.md" 2>/dev/null</arg_value><tool_call>find sports-betting -type f 2>/dev/null</arg_value>
